page.title: 20The River Severn - Pollution
page.content: by Ann Hill 1963 saw the last major flooding of the River Severn at Stourport, since then the increased use of dams built high up in the headwater areas have allowed man to control the river to some degree.An increase in motor boats and pleasure craft using this stretch of the Severn has resulted in many more moorings being used.The constant wash set up by increased boat traffic erodes the banks and muddies the once clear water leading to a loss of weed growth due to a lack of light and a subsiquent loss of habitat for millions of small water creatures. Oil and petrol spillages now often discolour the surface of the river in Summer and the engine noise of boats destroys the country sounds in the once peaceful country areas on this stretch of river below the town.
